title: 107_s1837
content: The establishment of a Board of Inquiry is outlined in Section 1. The Board of Inquiry into the September 11, 2001, Terrorist Attacks is established with 12 members appointed by the President, Senate Majority Leader, Senate Minority Leader, and Speaker of the House of Representatives. The Board of Inquiry into the September 11, 2001, Terrorist Attacks consists of 12 members appointed by various officials, including the President and leaders from the House of Representatives. Among the members, there are qualifications for individuals appointed from private life, who must have demonstrated ability and accomplishment in relevant fields such as government, business, law, or national security matters. The Board of Inquiry into the September 11, 2001, Terrorist Attacks consists of 12 members appointed by officials. Members must have a background in national security matters. Appointments should be made within thirty days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the life of the Board, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board selects a Chairman and Vice Chairman from its members. Meetings are called by the Chairman, with the first meeting held within fifteen days of all appointments. A majority of members constitutes a quorum. The Board of Inquiry into the September 11, 2001, Terrorist Attacks consists of 12 members appointed by officials with backgrounds in national security matters. A majority of the members constitute a quorum for hearings, testimony, or receiving evidence. The Board of Inquiry into the September 11, 2001, Terrorist Attacks is tasked with conducting a thorough study to identify systemic problems in intelligence and counter-terrorism efforts to prevent future attacks on the United States. The Board of Inquiry into the September 11, 2001, Terrorist Attacks will submit three reports to Congress: an initial plan for work within 30 days of the first meeting, a preliminary report within six months, and a final report within one year. Each report will contain findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. Each report under this section shall be submitted in unclassified form, with the possibility of a classified annex. The Board has powers as outlined in Section 4. The Board, or its subcommittee or member, may hold hearings, take testimony, and issue subpoenas to gather evidence for carrying out the Act. Subpoenas will be issued according to procedures established by the Board and served by individuals designated by the Chairman. Enforcement of subpoenas issued by the Board may be enforced by the United States district court, with failure to comply resulting in contempt charges. Witness allowances and fees will be in accordance with Section 1821 of title 28, United States Code. The Board can also obtain information from federal agencies. The Board has the authority to obtain information from federal agencies, use postal services, and accept gifts or donations. SEC. 5. PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Board are compensated based on their status as officers or employees of the Federal Government. Non-government members receive daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, while government members serve without additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, are provided for Board members while away from their homes or regular places of business. The Chairman of the Board has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The compensation for these positions can be determined by the Chairman without restrictions, as long as it does not exceed the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Board Chairman can appoint an executive director and staff without civil service restrictions, with compensation not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Board members and staff must have appropriate security clearances for classified information access. The Attorney General must expedite security clearance investigations within 60 days for new Board members. Federal employees can be detailed to the Board without reimbursement. The Chairman of the Board can procure temporary and intermittent services under specific regulations without exceeding certain pay rates. SEC. 6. APPLICABILITY OF CERTAIN ADMINISTRATIVE LAWS. The laws governing the protection of classified information apply to the Board members and staff. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Board's activities. The Freedom of Information Act does not apply to the Board's activities, except upon transfer to the National Archives. Upon transfer to the National Archives, records of the Board are subject to section 552 of title 5, United States Code. The provisions of title 44, United States Code, apply to the Board's records under this Act. The Board will terminate 30 days after submitting its final report. $1,500,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002 for the Board, with funds available without limitation until expended.
